The '''Supreme Committee for the Liberation of Lithuania''' or '''VLIK''' ({{lang-lt|Vyriausiasis Lietuvos išlaisvinimo komitetas}}) was an organization seeking independence of [[Lithuania]]. It was established on November 25, 1943, during the [[Occupation of Lithuania by Nazi Germany|Nazi occupation]]. After [[World War II]] it moved abroad and continued its operations in Germany and the United States. VLIK claimed to be the legal representative of the Lithuanian parliament and government, but did not enjoy international recognition. It was dissolved in 1990 when [[Act of the Re-Establishment of the State of Lithuania|Lithuania declared its independence]].
==In Lithuania== <!-- Deleted image removed: [[Image:Steponas Kairys.jpg|right|150px|thumb|Steponas Kairys, was the first chairman of the Committee]] --> When [[Nazi Germany]] [[Operation Barbarossa|invaded]] the [[Soviet Union]] in June 1941, [[Lithuanians]] greeted Germans as "liberators" from the oppressive Soviet regime. However, soon the attitude changed and various resistance movements began to form at the end of 1941 – beginning of 1942. During 1942 and 1943 these movements began consolidating into the pro-Catholic Nation's Council ({{lang-lt|Tautos taryba}}) and Supreme Committee of the Lithuanians ({{lang-lt|Vyriausiasis lietuvių komitetas}}).<ref name=lt243>{{cite book |editor=Arvydas Anušauskas|title=Lietuva, 1940–1990 |year=2005 |publisher=[[Lietuvos gyventojų genocido ir rezistencijos tyrimo centras]] |location=Vilnius |isbn=9986-757-65-7 |pages=243–244|language=lt|display-editors=etal}}</ref> After a five-month discussion, these two organizations decided to established one unified organization – VLIK, representing a wide range of political views.<ref name=lt243/> The first meeting of VLIK was held on November 25, 1943 in [[Kaunas]] and [[Steponas Kairys]] was elected the first chairman.<ref name=lt243/> VLIK's mission was to act as an [[government in exile|underground government]] until restoration of the Lithuanian independence. VLIK sent its envoys to Sweden and Finland, maintained contacts with Lithuanian diplomats in Switzerland, and attempted to inform the western powers about the crimes perpetrated by the Nazis.<ref name=lt243/> VLIK published underground newspapers and agitated for [[passive resistance]] against the Nazis.<ref name=vardys>{{cite book|first=Vytas Stanley |last=Vardys |author2=Judith B. Sedaitis |title=Lithuania: The Rebel Nation |publisher=WestviewPress |year=1997 |series=Westview Series on the Post-Soviet Republics |isbn=0-8133-1839-4 |page=57}}</ref> They thought that their biggest enemy was still the Soviet Union and that resources should be conserved for [[Lithuanian partisans (1944–1953)|the upcoming armed resistance]] against the Russians.<ref name=vardys/>
In early 1944 VLIK sent colonel Kazimieras Amraziejus on a mission to [[Stockholm]], but he was captured and interrogated by the [[Gestapo]] in Estonia. This led to arrests of eight VLIK members on April 29–30, 1944.<ref name=ger347>{{cite book | last=Budreckis | first=Algirdas | editor=Albertas Gerutis | others=translated by Algirdas Budreckis | title=Lithuania: 700 Years | year=1984 | edition=6th | publisher=Manyland Books | location=New York | id={{LCC | 75-80057}} |isbn=0-87141-028-1 | pages=347–348 | chapter=Lithuanian Resistance, 1940–52 }}</ref> In 1944, when the Soviets pushed the Germans from the [[Baltic states]] during the [[Baltic Offensive (1944)|Baltic Offensive]], most of VLIK members retreated to Germany and VLIK ceased its functions in Lithuania.<ref name=lt243/> VLIK originally designed three of its members to remain in Lithuania, but only one did. It was a strategic loss as communication with Lithuania was severed and there was very little contact with remaining resistance groups.<ref name=ger347/>
==In exile== Functions of VLIK were resumed in October 1944 in [[Würzburg]], but soon moved to [[Reutlingen]] ahead of the approaching [[Red Army]].<ref>{{cite book | last=Budreckis | first=Algirdas | editor=Albertas Gerutis | others=translated by Algirdas Budreckis | title=Lithuania: 700 Years | year=1984 | edition=6th | publisher=Manyland Books | location=New York | id={{LCC | 75-80057}} |isbn=0-87141-028-1 | page=394 | chapter=Liberation Attempts from Abrod }}</ref> VLIK remained in Reutlingen until 1955. [[Mykolas Krupavičius]] became the new chairman. VLIK united 15 different political organizations,<ref>{{cite encyclopedia | editor=Simas Sužiedėlis | encyclopedia=[[Encyclopedia Lituanica]] | title=Supreme Committee for the Liberation of Lithuania | year=1970–1978 | publisher=Juozas Kapočius | volume=V | location=Boston, Massachusetts | id={{LCC | 74-114275}} | pages=326–327}}</ref> whose members held a variety of political views and that hindered decision making.<ref name=lt376>{{cite book |editor=Arvydas Anušauskas|title=Lietuva, 1940–1990 |year=2005 |publisher=[[Lietuvos gyventojų genocido ir rezistencijos tyrimo centras]] |location=Vilnius |isbn=9986-757-65-7 |pages=376–377|language=lt|display-editors=etal}}</ref> In July 1945, before the [[Potsdam Conference]], VLIK sent memorandums to [[Winston Churchill]] and [[Harry S. Truman]] asking not to recognize Lithuania's occupation by the Soviet Union and asking for help reestablishing independent Lithuania.<ref name=ger405>{{cite book | last=Budreckis | first=Algirdas | editor=Albertas Gerutis | others=translated by Algirdas Budreckis | title=Lithuania: 700 Years | year=1984 | edition=6th | publisher=Manyland Books | location=New York | id={{LCC | 75-80057}} |isbn=0-87141-028-1 | pages=405–407 | chapter=Liberation Attempts from Abrod }}</ref> Numerous further notes were sent to the [[United Nations]], various diplomats, academics, journalists promoting their cause and reporting [[Human rights in the Soviet Union|human right violations]] in Lithuania. VLIK also reestablished [[ELTA]] news service, including radio broadcasts.<ref name=ger405/> VLIK attempted to establish contacts with the [[Lithuanian partisans (1944–1953)|armed resistance in Lithuania]], but had only limited communication with [[Juozas Lukša]].
VLIK positioned itself as the Lithuanian [[Seimas]] (the parliament) and claimed that its executives were equivalent of a [[cabinet (government)|cabinet]].<ref name=lt376/> Despite its claims, VLIK was not recognized by any foreign country as a representative of Lithuania. It further claimed that Lithuanian diplomats, still active in pre-war embassies of independent Lithuania, were subordinates to VLIK.<ref name=lt376/> This caused decade-long disagreements with [[Stasys Lozoraitis]], who was in charge of the diplomatic service and had a back-dated appointment as Prime Minister by the last President of Lithuania [[Antanas Smetona]]. This tension was one of the reasons why the Lithuanians were unable to form a recognized [[government-in-exile]].<ref name=lt387>{{cite book |editor=Arvydas Anušauskas|title=Lietuva, 1940–1990 |year=2005 |publisher=[[Lietuvos gyventojų genocido ir rezistencijos tyrimo centras]] |location=Vilnius |isbn=9986-757-65-7 |page=387|language=lt|display-editors=etal}}</ref> Several attempts were made to ease the tension between VLIK (representing the nation) and the diplomatic service (representing the state).<ref name=ger405/> The first was a conference in [[Berne]] in July 1946. It was decided to form an Executive Council, but it never took off.<ref name=lt38806>{{cite book |editor=Arvydas Anušauskas|title=Lietuva, 1940–1990 |year=2005 |publisher=[[Lietuvos gyventojų genocido ir rezistencijos tyrimo centras]] |location=Vilnius |isbn=9986-757-65-7 |page=380|language=lt|display-editors=etal}}</ref> The second conference was held in [[Paris]] in August 1947.
As war refugees moved out of the [[displaced persons camp]]s to the United States, VLIK also moved its headquarters to [[New York City]] in 1955. After the move, VLIK's political agenda became less prominent. The activists realized that there will be no quick solution to the [[Cold War]]. VLIK's main goal was to maintain non-recognition of Lithuania’s occupation and dissemination of information from behind the [[iron curtain]].<ref>{{cite journal |first=Mintautas |last=Bložė |url=http://www.lfpr.lt/uploads/File/2000-5/Lietuvos_diplomatija.pdf |title=Lietuvos diplomatija XX amžiuje (review) |journal=Lithuanian Foreign Policy Review |year=2000 |volume=1 |issue=5 |issn=1392-5504 |page=4 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110722135924/http://www.lfpr.lt/uploads/File/2000-5/Lietuvos_diplomatija.pdf |archivedate=2011-07-22 |df= }}</ref> VLIK established the [[Lithuanian World Community]] with a mission to promote Lithuanian language and culture among Lithuanians living abroad. Eventually VLIK ceased to exist after Lithuania declared independence in 1990.<ref>{{cite web | first=Kazys | last=Blaževičius |authorlink= | title=Likimo vedami | date=2004 | publisher= | url =http://www.xxiamzius.lt/archyvas/xxiamzius/20040128/liter_01.html | work = | pages = | accessdate = 2009-03-25 | language = Lithuanian }}</ref>
==Chairmen== VLIK's chairmen were:<ref name=miklas>{{cite book |editor-first=Kęstutis |editor-last=Miklas |title=Tautos Fondas (Lithuanian National Foundation, Inc.) 1943-2002 |url=https://books.google.com/books?id=HKkXV9p0mg0C&pg=PA68 |publisher=Lithuanian National Foundation |year=2002 |location=New York |isbn=0971814406 |page=68 |language=lt}}</ref> * [[Steponas Kairys]] (25 November 1943 – 10 March 1979) * [[Mykolas Krupavičius]] (15 June 1945 – 27 November 1955) * Jonas Matulionis (27 November 1955 – 1 June 1957) * Antanas Trimakas (1 June 1957 – 27 February 1964) * Juozas Audėnas (27 February 1964 – 3 October 1964) * Kipras Bielinis (3 October 1964 – 29 November 1964) * [[Vaclovas Sidzikauskas]] (29 November 1964 – 11 December 1966) * Juozas Kęstutis Valiūnas (11 December 1966 – 24 March 1979) * [[Kazys Bobelis]] (24 March 1979 – 31 May 1992)

{{primary sources|date=July 2012}} {{Infobox non-profit | name = Syrian Revolution Coordinators Union ({{lang|ar|اتحاد تنسيقيات الثورة السورية}}) | image = [[File:SRCU-Square-Logo 300x300.jpg|SRCU-Square-Logo 300x300.jpg]] | type = Organization/Network | founded_date = {{start date|2011|03}} | tax_id = | registration_id = | founder = | location = [[Syria]] | coordinates = 33.5184992376561, 36.30157470703125 | origins = | key_people = [[Ibrahem Koki]] <ref>url=https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=qHSbAejxWrg&feature=youtu.be</ref> | area_served = | product = | mission = | focus = "Toppling Criminal Assad Regime & Building a democratic Syria" | method = [[civil disobedience]], [[protests]], [[General strike|strike]]s | revenue = | endowment = | num_volunteers = | num_employees = | num_members = 200–300 (May 2011) | subsid = | non-profit_slogan = | former name = | homepage = {{URL|syrcu.org}} | dissolved = | footnotes = }}
The '''Syrian Revolution Coordinators Union''' or (SYRCU) ({{lang-ar|اتحاد تنسيقيات الثورة السورية}}) is an organization with members from different protest coordination groups from all around Syria. Its members represent their areas and cities for the activities of the Syrian uprising that began in 2011 against the Syrian government. The Syrian Revolution Coordinators Union'' has been active since the beginning of the revolution in [[Nonviolent resistance|peaceful resistance]]
The Union includes more than 216 coordination group, local council and group of activists of the protests in Syria. It aims to "end to the ruling of the 40-years-old [[al-Assad family]] ruling Syria, particularly after that government started using lethal force against peaceful protest asking for reform and freedom in May 2011 in the southern Syrian city of [[Daraa]]". The '''SRCU''' aims to "build Syria as country of [[democracy]] and [[rule of law]]; where [[civil rights|civil]] and [[human rights]] are obeyed by citizens and authorities".
== Supporting Social Journalism== The Union has helped a number of individual activists and social journalists to relay the news about their areas by providing basic equipment and training.
== Projects == * Syrian FM opposition radio station. * The ROP Project (Will be launched soon)
== Humanitarian & Medical Work == The '''Syrian Revolution Coordinators Union''' has conducted, through its local humanitarian and medical member groups, many humanitarian activities and field hospitals equipment. Particularly since the government's activities has practically disabled the work of any Syrian or foreign NGOs to help injured people and refugees.{{Citation needed|date=January 2015}} The '''SRCU''' has provided through donors inside and out [[Syria]] a number of food boxes, shift clinic equipment and medical supplies to different areas in distress.
Since the beginning of the [[Syrian uprising (2011–present)|Syrian uprising]] against the government, any civilian or protester injured by the regime forces, army or [[Shabiha]] militias will have to be treated by volunteer medics or doctors in improvised sites, houses or dedicated shift clinics.{{Citation needed|date=January 2015}} Equipping and hiding field treatment locations has been one of the most threatening and resources consuming task during the uprising.{{Citation needed|date=January 2015}} The government security forces in a number of occasions used local paid informants to locate and destroy treatment locations equipped by the SRCU.{{Citation needed|date=January 2015}}
== SYRCU Approach ==
The '''Syrian Revolution Coordinators Union''' (SYRCU) is a civilian, non-for-profit entity that gathers coordinators of anti-government protests from all around Syria. The SYRCU claims it believes in "protests, strikes, social campaigns, civil disobedience and other non-violent tools as the most efficient ones to achieve the goal of the [[Syrian uprising (2011–present)|Syrian revolution]]". The SYRCU also believes that this is the best life-saving approach in the Syrian people struggle to achieve democracy and build Syria as a country for everyone to share, rather than just a single family to control, i.e. Assad Family.
Even though we the SYRCU does not take up arms to for their cause, they still believe in the legitimacy of the fight that defected officers and soldiers, ex-military personnel and other have decided to take. Those people who are now called the [[Free Syrian Army]] (FSA) have seen families murdered in cold blood in front in their own eyes and decided that they should defend their neighborhoods, families and property using a lethal forces that is so little compared to that used by the [[Assad family]] government.
The '''Syrian Revolution Coordinators Union''' (SYRCU) believes that medical care and humanitarian aid should be provided to any one in need regardless of their belonging. This even applies to arrested soldiers who were just fighting to the Assad government's side. They also believe and approve of the International conventions in this regard, including but not limited to the four Geneva Conventions and the three protocols agreed upon after them.
The SYRCU also believes that the international community, represented by its major entities like the United Nations, the Arab League and others, are and should be always responsible for making everyone who commits crimes against the Syrian people become accounted by the law. They have supported all the plans presented by the international community in such context including the initiative by Kofi Anan that aimed to end the violence and release all prisoners. Considering all the plans that have been presented, the SYRCU has made it clear several times before that it aims for exactly the same points. The SYRCU believe in its rights to keep its social movement and refuse any dialogue with the government before it withdraws the army from the cities, release all political prisoners and activists, confess to the crimes it did and become prepared to hand-over the power in Syria.

{{Infobox religion | name = Zuism
Sumerian-Mesopotamian Neopaganism | image = File:Zuist Church logo (December 2017).svg|Zuist Church logo (December 2017) | imagewidth = 100px | founded_date = 1980s (early informal groups), 2010 (Icelandic institutionalisation) | founded_place = Iceland | type = [[Neopagan]] [[new religious movement]] | main_classification = [[Sumerian religion]] | area = Mostly Iceland, central and northern Europe | website = http://zuism.is/ | members = 1,923 (Iceland 2018){{cite web|url=https://px.hagstofa.is/pxen/pxweb/en/Samfelag/Samfelag__menning__5_trufelog/MAN10001.px/?rxid=e9b67606-d567-44f2-a62d-92903ddcca5d|title=Populations by religious and life stance organisations|publisher=[[Statistics Iceland]]}} }} [[File:Relief Im-dugud Louvre AO2783.jpg|thumb|150px|Zu, Imdugud, the thunderbird.]] '''Zuism''' or '''Sumerian-Mesopotamian Neopaganism'''{{refn|group=note|The name '''Zuism''' has become the most common descriptor for the modern movement of Sumerian-Mesopotamian religion, being the name under which the religion has been recognised by the Icelandic government since 2013. Other descriptors have been used, by minor informal groups which existed before the recognition under Icelandic law. These synonyms include '''Sumerian-Mesopotamian Neopaganism''' or '''Sumerian-Mesopotamian Reconstructionism''', '''Babylonian Neopaganism''' or '''Babylonian Reconstructionism''', and '''Kaldanism''' ("way of the Chaldeans").{{sfnm|1a1=Ansbrandt|1y=2018a|2a1=Ansbrandt|2y=2018b|2loc=zuism.it version, note i}}}} define a [[modern Paganism|modern Pagan]] [[religion|religious]] movement based on the [[Sumerian religion]] (and later [[ancient Mesopotamian religion|Mesopotamian religion]]s which continued it),{{sfn|Bromley|2018}} and calls itself the "oldest religion, foundation of all major religions".{{cite web|title=How it all began|url=http://zuist.org/about/our-story/|website=Zuism International|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20180123195316/http://zuist.org/about/our-story/|archive-date=23 January 2018}} Modern Sumerian-Mesopotamian religious groups already existed since the 1980s;{{sfn|Ansbrandt|2018a}} however, the first institutional form of the movement was founded in [[Iceland]] in 2010 by Ólafur Helgi Þorgrímsson, and in 2013 Zuism was registered among the religions recognised by the Icelandic government.{{sfn|Bromley|2018}} After the mid-2010s, branches of the church were established in other countries of central and northern Europe.{{sfn|Bromley|2018}} In late 2015 the Zuist Church of Iceland was taken over by a new leadership, under which the church was turned into a medium for a mass protest against the nationally mandated tax on religious membership; Icelanders began converting in large numbers as the new leadership promised that the tax received by the Zuist Church would have been used to refund the church members themselves.{{cite web|author=Harriet Sherwood|title=Icelanders flock to religion revering Sumerian deities and tax rebates|url=https://www.theguardian.com/world/2015/dec/08/new-icelandic-religion-sumerian-gods-tax-rebates-zuism|website=The Guardian|date=8 December 2015|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20171220220005/https://www.theguardian.com/world/2015/dec/08/new-icelandic-religion-sumerian-gods-tax-rebates-zuism|archive-date=20 December 2017}} After a legal struggle, in 2017 the original directors of the church were restored to power. They decided to maintain the previous leaders' principle of refunding church members,{{cite web|title=Zúistar búnir að endurgreiða sóknargjöldin|url=http://zuism.is/2017/11/16/zuistar-bunir-ad-endurgreida-soknargjoldin/|website=Zúistar á Íslandi|date=16 November 2017|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20171220215625/http://zuism.is/2017/11/16/zuistar-bunir-ad-endurgreida-soknargjoldin/|archive-date=20 December 2017}} and also to devolve funds to social welfare institutions.{{cite web|title=Zúistar hefja endurgreiðslur á sóknargjöldum upp úr miðjum nóvember|url=http://zuism.is/2017/11/03/zuistar-hefja-endurgreidslur-a-soknargjoldum-upp-ur-midjum-november/|website=Zúistar á Íslandi|date=3 November 2017|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20171220215737/http://zuism.is/2017/11/03/zuistar-hefja-endurgreidslur-a-soknargjoldum-upp-ur-midjum-november/|archive-date=20 December 2017}}{{cite web|title=Zuism styrkir Kvennaathvarfið um eina milljón króna|url=http://zuism.is/2017/12/08/zuism-styrkir-kvennaathvarfid-um-eina-milljon-krona/|website=Zúistar á Íslandi|date=8 December 2017|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20171220215829/http://zuism.is/2017/12/08/zuism-styrkir-kvennaathvarfid-um-eina-milljon-krona/|archive-date=20 December 2017}} Zuism has spread considerably in Iceland by attracting members among younger, internet-connected, less Christian generations of Icelanders.{{sfn|Boldyreva|Grishina|2017}} ==Terminology== Modern Sumerian-Mesopotamin religion has been known as "Zuism", "Sumerian-Mesopotamian Neopaganism" or "Sumerian-Mesopotamian Reconstructionism", "Babylonian Neopaganism" or "Babylonian Reconstructionism", and "Kaldanism" (which means "way of Chaldeans", [[Chaldea]] being a late term for [[Sumer]]). Among them, Zuism has become the most popular descriptor for the movement, by virtue of being the name under which the religion is recognised by Icelandic law.{{sfn|Ansbrandt|2018a}} Zuism is defined as an international religious movement which intends to represent all the groups professing Sumerian-Mesopotamian religions. The Zuist Church of Iceland, the orgaisation recognised by the Icelandic government, has established branches throughout various countries and intends to be a platform for all Zuist believers. Many Zuists and Sumerian-Mesopotamian Neopagans are contributing to the development of the movement both within and outside the Zuist Church.{{sfn|Ansbrandt|2018a}} The name "Zuism" originates from the Sumerian verb ''zu'' {{cuneiform|𒍪}}, meaning "to know",{{sfn|Wolfe|2015}} and is defined as a "way of knowledge", of knowing the appropriate modality of being human, in harmony with divinity. It is equated with the Greek term ''[[gnosis]]''.{{sfn|Ansbrandt|2018a}} The term ''zu'' may also refer to the thunder-bird god of wisdom, ''[[Anzû|Zû]]'',{{cite web|title=Mais pourquoi des milliers d'Islandais se convertissent au zuisme?|url=http://www.bfmtv.com/international/mais-pourquoi-des-milliers-d-islandais-se-convertissent-au-zuisme-936288.html|website=BFMTV|date=11 December 2015|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20171220220657/http://www.bfmtv.com/international/mais-pourquoi-des-milliers-d-islandais-se-convertissent-au-zuisme-936288.html|archive-date=20 December 2017}} servant of [[Enlil]]. ==Beliefs and practices== [[File:Zuist calendar.svg|thumb|250px|Astronomical calendar for Zuism—map of the constellations spinning around the north celestial pole;{{sfn|Didier|2009|pp=95, Vol. I}} An is the whole of the map and the [[orbital pole|ecliptic north pole]] itself, within the coil of the constellation [[Draco (constellation)|Draco]] (here not represented).{{sfn|Rogers|1998|p=21}}
— The darkest-blue ring just around the centre are the constellations of the "Path of Enlil", constituting the northern or inner sky, with Enlil himself specifically identified as ''Mul.apin'', [[Triangulum]], the enclosure highlighted by the red line. Enlil's female, Ninlil, is the ''Mar.gid.da'', the Great Chariot, in the same ring.{{sfn|Rogers|1998|p=18}}
— The lightest-blue ring are the constellations of the "Path of Enki", constituting the southern or outer sky, with Enki ("Lord of the Squared Earth") himself specifically identifies as ''Mul.iku'', the [[Square of Pegasus]], highlighted by the red line.{{sfn|Rogers|1998|p=21}}
— The medium-blue ring between the inner Path of Enlil and the outer Path of Enki is the "Path of An".{{sfn|Didier|2009|pp=95, Vol. I}}]] Zuism is defined as the knowledge on how to appropriately stand in-between Heaven ({{cuneiform|𒀭}} ''An'' or ''Dingir'') and Earth ({{cuneiform|𒆠}} ''Ki''), by acting in accordance with the creative word ({{cuneiform|𒌓}} ''utu'') and the measures ({{cuneiform|𒈨}} ''me'') represented by the gods ({{cuneiform|𒀭}} ''dingir''), all constituting the energetic ''[[logos]]'' ({{cuneiform|𒆤}} ''lil'') of Heaven.{{sfn|Ansbrandt|2018a}} ===Theology=== Gods are held to be immortal beings, who are human-like and yet invisible to human eyes. They are potencies who guide the development of the universe. The four main divine beings are:{{cite web|title=Kennisetningar Zuism|url=http://is.zuist.org/about/our-mission/|website=Zuism Iceland|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20180116084124/http://is.zuist.org/about/our-mission/|archive-date=16 January 2018}} ① the [[universe|universal]] god ''[[Anu (god)|An]]''/''[[Dingir]]'' (literally "Heaven"/"God", astrally identified as the [[orbital pole|ecliptic]] north [[celestial pole]] encompassed by the coil of the constellation [[Draco (constellation)|Draco]], and with all the constellations spinning around it;{{sfn|Rogers|1998|p=21}}{{sfn|Didier|2009|pp=261–265, Vol. III}} the [[Ursa Minor|Little Bear]] is his chariot, ''Mar.gid.da.an.na'', the "Chariot of Heaven"{{sfn|Rogers|1998|p=18}}), ② ''[[Ki (goddess)|Ki]]'' or ''[[Ninhursag]]'' (literally "Earth" or "Lady of the Mountain"), ③ ''[[Enki]]'' (literally "Lord of the Squared Earth", the god of water and craft, astrally identified as ''Aš.iku'' or ''Mul.iku'', the "Field", that is the [[Square of Pegasus]], and generally with the southern sky—called Path of Enki—, that is to say the circle farther from the north celestial pole An{{sfn|Rogers|1998|p=21}}{{sfn|Didier|2009|pp=95, Vol. I}}) and ④ ''[[Enlil]]'' (literally "Lord of the Storm", the god of weather and thunder, identified as ''Mul.apin'', the "Plough", that is the constellation [[Triangulum]], and generally with the northern sky—called Path of Enlil—, that is to say the circle nearest to the north celestial pole An; his wife ''[[Ninlil]]'', literally "Lady of the Storm", is ''Mar.gid.da'', the "[[Big Dipper|Chariot]]"{{sfn|Rogers|1998|p=18}}{{sfn|Didier|2009|pp=95, Vol. I}}). Sky, earth, air and water are thus considered the fundamental elements of the cosmos. Lesser deities include [[Sin (mythology)|Nanna]] (the moon), [[Utu]] (the sun), [[Marduk]] (represented with a sword and a dragon, astrally identified as [[Jupiter]],{{sfn|Rogers|1998|p=12}} and also associated with the north celestial pole An{{sfn|Didier|2009|p=265, Vol. III}}), [[Nabu]] (god of writing and wisdom, astrally identified as [[Mercury (planet)|Mercury]]{{sfn|Rogers|1998|p=12}}), [[Nergal]] (god of the underworld and plagues, astrally identified as [[Mars]]{{sfn|Rogers|1998|p=12}}), [[Ninurta]] (god of war and farming, astrally identified as [[Saturn]]{{sfn|Rogers|1998|p=13}}), [[Inanna]] (goddess of love, beauty, creativity and war; astrally identified as [[Venus]]{{sfn|Rogers|1998|p=11}}) and [[Tammuz (mythology)|Dumuzi]] (shepherd god of death and resurrection, astrally identified as [[Aries (constellation)|Aries]]{{sfn|Rogers|1998|p=14}}). ===Ethics and scripture recitation=== The universe is created by the gods through the word, ''utu'' ({{cuneiform|𒌓}}), and developed through the measures, ''[[me (mythology)|me]]'' {{cuneiform|𒈨}}.{{sfn|Earliest Leaders of Zuism Iceland|2010}}{{cite web|title=Kennisetningar Zuism|url=http://is.zuist.org/about/our-mission/|website=Zuism Iceland|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20180116084124/http://is.zuist.org/about/our-mission/|archive-date=16 January 2018}} The divine word (''utu'') which has performative power, is the power to create. By the words of the founders and earliest leaders, the "act of creation ... was accomplished through utterance of the divine word". The deity "had merely to make plans and pronounce the name of the thing to be created".{{sfn|Earliest Leaders of Zuism Iceland|2010}} The measures (''me'') are "universal and unchangeable rules and laws that all beings are obliged to obey", which "keep the cosmos in continuous and harmonious operation and ... avoid confusion and conflict".{{sfn|Earliest Leaders of Zuism Iceland|2010}} Belief and practice of Zuism is based on Sumerian poems, which Zuists recite in their worship services in honour of the gods.{{cite web|title=Icelanders flocking to the Zuist religion|url=http://icelandmonitor.mbl.is/news/politics_and_society/2015/12/01/icelanders_flocking_to_the_zuist_religion/|website=Iceland Monitor|date=1 December 2015|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20171220220248/http://icelandmonitor.mbl.is/news/politics_and_society/2015/12/01/icelanders_flocking_to_the_zuist_religion/|archive-date=20 December 2017}} Regular gatherings are held for such scripture recitation in honour of the gods, as well as for prayers, which are either personal or for the welfare of others. Believers conduct their daily life according to the ''me'', which in human society are ethical codes modeled after the laws of the universe, and govern every aspect of morality from individual to social economy. Zuism is a "social religion", meaning that men and gods are considered symbiotic parts of the same complex whole. Gods govern the fate of men, and relationship with them may not be forsaken. Chiefs and priests are responsible for upkeeping the relationship with the gods through daily, monthly and yearly ordinances held at temples. Priests are called ''en'', ''ensi'' and ''[[lugal]]''. ===Annulment of debt and wealth redistribution=== {{Further|Ama-gi}} According to the Zuist Church, [[Sumer]] had the earliest tax system in the history of civilisation for which archeological attestations exist; it was called ''bala''. Sumerians were aware of the threat posed to economies by the accumulation of debt, and for this reason debt was regularly annulled. This practice was called ''amagi'' ({{cuneiform|𒂼𒄄}}) or ''amargi'' ({{cuneiform|𒂼𒅈𒄄}}), literally "return to the mother", and the Zuist Church aims to restore it for today, starting with the redistribution among members of the wealth received through the tax on religious membership which governments—including that of Iceland—impose on their citizens.{{cite web|title=Amargi (Endurgreiðsla Sóknargjalda)|url=http://zuism.is/endurgreidsla-soknargjalda/|website=Zúistar á Íslandi|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20171229135343/http://zuism.is/endurgreidsla-soknargjalda/|archive-date=29 December 2017}} ====Charity==== The members of the Zuist Church of Iceland may choose whether to devolve their paid taxes to charity. In 2017, the Zuist Church devolved funds to a number of social welfare organisations: 1.1 million [[Icelandic crown]]s were donated to the Circle Children's Hospital (''Barnaspítala Hringsins''), 1 million to the Women's Shelter (''Kvennaathvarfsins''), and 300 thousand Icelandic crowns to the emergency fund of the [[UNICEF]]. With the help of its members, according to the leader Ágúst Arnar Ágústsson, the Zuist Church may become "a long-term sponsor of such organisations". ==Temple and burial ground== [[File:Ekur of Enlil, Reykjavík.jpg|thumb|400px|Project of the Ekur of [[Enlil]] to be built in Reykjavík.]] On 16 January 2018, the Zuist Church of Iceland applied for the allocation of a plot of land in [[Reykjavík]] for the burial of its members.{{cite web|url=http://www.kirkjugardar.is/pdf/fundargerdir/20180116.pdf|title=Fundargerð framkvæmdastjórnar KGR|publisher=Cemeteries of Reykjavík Deanery (Kirkjugaðar Reykjavíkurprófastsdæma – KGRP)|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20180609014420/http://www.kirkjugardar.is/pdf/fundargerdir/20180116.pdf|archive-date=9 June 2018}} On 29 May of the same year, the Zuists of Iceland presented the project and applied for the allocation of land for building a temple in the capital, which will be called the Ekur of Enlil (literally "Mount-Court of Enlil" or "Temple-Mount of Enlil"). It will function as the headquarters of the Zuist Church and as the main site for religious rituals, including baptisms and weddings. The temple will be on three levels, a ground floor and a first floor dedicated to community activities, and a shrine to the deity on the second floor. The Zuist Church opened a "fund for the ziggurat" (''Zigguratsjóð'') to which members will choose whether to devolve their taxes.{{cite web|title=Zuism sækir um lóð í Reykjavík|url=http://zuism.is/2018/05/29/zuism-saekir-um-lod-i-reykjavik/|website=Zúistar á Íslandi|date=29 May 2018|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20180609014312/http://zuism.is/2018/05/29/zuism-saekir-um-lod-i-reykjavik/|archive-date=9 June 2018}} ==History== ===1980s–2000s=== Before the establishment of the Zuist Church in Iceland, there were already some Zuist or Sumerian-Mesopotamian Neopagan groups, mostly small and informal, many of which still exist, including the Temple of Sumer.{{cite web|url=http://templeofsumer.com/|title=Temple of Sumer}} The Sumerian-Mesopotamian contemporary [[new religious movement]], indeed, dates back at least to the 1980s.{{sfn|Ansbrandt|2018a}} According to the Zuist Church of Iceland, its history may be further traced back well before the 2010s to a "mother church" of Icelandic believers who dwelt in [[Delaware]], [[United States]].{{sfn|Ansbrandt|2018a}}{{cite web|title=Sagan okkar|url=http://is.zuist.org/about/our-story/|website=Zuism Iceland|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20180116080208/http://is.zuist.org/about/our-story/|archive-date=16 January 2018}} ===2010s=== ====Zuist Church of Iceland==== =====2013–2014: official registration and Ágúst Arnar's leadership===== Zuism became a recognised religion in Iceland in 2013, when Icelandic law was amended to allow further non-Christian religions to be registered with the state.{{sfn|Bromley|2018}} The Zuist Church was founded years before, in 2010, by Ólafur Helgi Þorgrímsson,{{sfn|Bromley|2018}} who left it at an early stage of development.{{cite web|title=Dularfyllsta trúfélag á Íslandi verður brottfellt á næstunni|url=https://stundin.is/frett/dularfyllsta-trufelag-islandi-verdur-brottfellt-na/|website=Stundin|date=14 April 2015|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20171220221047/https://stundin.is/frett/dularfyllsta-trufelag-islandi-verdur-brottfellt-na/|archive-date=20 December 2017}} The current head priest of the Zuist Church of Iceland is Ágúst Arnar Ágústsson,{{cite web|url=http://www.syslumenn.is/thjonusta/utgefin-leyfi/listi-yfir-skrad-trufelog-og-lifsskodunarfelog/|title=Listi yfir skráð trúfélög og lífsskoðunarfélög|publisher=[[Sýslumaður|Sýslumenn]]}} who took on the office in September 2014.{{cite web|title=Yfirlýsing frá Ágústi Arnari Ágústsssyni, forstöðumanni trúfélagsins Zuism|url=http://zuism.is/2017/10/24/yfirlysing-fra-agusti-arnari-agustsssyni-forstodumanni-trufelagsins-zuism/|website=Zúistar á Íslandi|date=24 October 2017|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20171220221401/http://zuism.is/2017/10/24/yfirlysing-fra-agusti-arnari-agustsssyni-forstodumanni-trufelagsins-zuism/|archive-date=20 December 2017}} ====Zuist Church of Britain==== The Zuist Church of Britain was first established in 2013,{{cite web|url=https://beta.companieshouse.gov.uk/company/11181258|title=Zuism Limited – Company number 08457281|publisher=[[Companies House]], [[Government of the United Kingdom]]}} and then re-established in 2018.{{cite web|url=https://beta.companieshouse.gov.uk/company/11181258/officers|title=Zuism Ltd – Company number 11181258|publisher=[[Companies House]], [[Government of the United Kingdom]]}} It is headquartered in [[Islington]], [[London]] and led by Soley Rut Magnusdottir besides Ágúst Arnar and his brother Einar. ====Zuist Church of Denmark==== A branch of the Zuist Church was established in Denmark after the mid-2010s.{{cite web|url=http://dk.zuist.org/|title=Zuism Denmark}} ====Zuist Church of Germany==== A branch of the Zuist Church was established in Germany after the mid-2010s.{{cite web|url=http://de.zuist.org/|title=Zuism Germany}} ====Zuist Church of Norway==== A branch of Zuism was established in 2016, in [[Norway]], as the "Congregation of Zuism in Norway", headquartered in [[Nittedal]].{{cite web|url=https://www.regnskapstall.no/informasjon-om-the-congregation-of-zuism-in-norway-105422824S0|title=Congregation of Zuism in Norway|publisher=Regnskapstall for alle bedrifter i Norge}} As of 2017 it was waiting to be registered as a recognised religion by the Norwegian government as the Zuist Church of Norway.{{cite web|url=http://no.zuist.org/|title=Zuism Norway}} ====Zuist Church of Sweden==== Another branch of the Zuist Church was established in [[Sweden]] around the same time as the Norwegian branch. The Zuist Church of Sweden's headquarters are located in [[Malmö]].{{cite web|title=Where you can find us|website=Zuism Sweden|url=http://se.zuist.org/contact/}} ====Zuist Church of Switzerland==== In 2015, a Swiss branch, the Zuist Church of Switzerland, was founded.{{cite web|url=http://ch.zuist.org/|title=Zuism Switzerland}} ==Views on Christianity and Sitchinianism== According to the independent Zuist author Uligang Ansbrandt, Christianity (viewed as corrupted and dying in its modern forms) and Islam are "false religions, or non-religions", as they "fail to relink Heaven, Earth and humanity" — the word "religion" is derived from the common root of the Latin verbs ''religere'' (careful "re-reading" or "re-collecting" right practices) and ''religare'' ("re-linking"), according, respectively, to the etymologies provided by [[Cicero]]'s ''[[De Rerum Natura]]'' and [[Lactantius]]' ''[[The Divine Institutes|Divinae Institutiones]]''.{{sfn|Ansbrandt|2018b|p=2, notes i and iii}} The Zuist vision of God is presented as a thisworldly one, in which God is "the starry sky and its cycles". The God as conceived by Abrahamic religions in instead presented as a "non-existing, otherworldly abstract thing".{{sfn|Ansbrandt|2018b|p=2, note i}} The author also rejects [[Zecharia Sitchin|Sitchinianism]], defined as another "abstract, nonsense science fiction", a misinterpretation of ancient knowledge which is worryingly "very popular nowadays".{{sfn|Ansbrandt|2018b|p=2, note
